text.style: text-decoration:none; vertical-align:baseline;

para.text: Create a .NET Minimal API (.NET) project and install (controllers are not required by the framework)

para.text: There are no rules how are you create your folder structure, this is up to you, but in the example I will be creating a folder called FeatureDemo. This example, I will be simply return back

text.style: text-decoration:none; vertical-align:baseline;

list.style: text-indent:-20px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:40px; line-height:1.00; tabstops:none; font-family:Calibri; font-size:11pt; color:#000000;

text.style: text-decoration:none; vertical-align:baseline;
text-decoration:none; vertical-align:baseline;

li.text: Under the folder "Features", Create Folder caller "FeatureDemo"

text.style: text-decoration:none; vertical-align:baseline;

li.text: Under the "Feature" create a folder called "Models"

text.style: text-decoration:none; vertical-align:baseline;

li.text: Under Models, create a class called RequestModel with a public string property called "FullName".

text.style: text-decoration:none; vertical-align:baseline;

li.text: Under Models create another called ResponseModel with a public string property called "FirstName"

text.style: text-decoration:none; vertical-align:baseline;

li.text: Under the Feature folder, create a class called CreateCustomerFeature that inherits from Command<RequestModel,ResponseModel>

text.style: text-decoration:none; vertical-align:baseline;

li.text: Last step, you will need to override a single method ProcessAsync (this is where your core logic will reside)

text.style: text-decoration:none; vertical-align:baseline;

para.text: Your Command Feature should look something like:

para.text: The above is just an example at this stage and will not cover every aspect of the framework at this stage.

text.style: text-decoration:none; vertical-align:baseline;

para.text: Now we need to register the feature with the core framework, this can be done in the program class.
